content.text: Ophthalmia neonatorum is conjunctivitis occurring within the first month of life. It can be caused by chemical irritation (from prophylactic agents), or more commonly, by bacterial or viral infections acquired during passage through the birth canal. Key pathogens include Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, which can cause severe infections. Other bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae) and viruses (e.g., Herpes Simplex Virus) are also potential causes.

rows: Mild injection and tearing, resolves spontaneously within 2-4 days.
Hyperacute, copious purulent discharge, marked eyelid edema. A medical emergency.
Mucopurulent discharge, conjunctival congestion, eyelid swelling. Most common infectious cause.
Serosanguineous discharge, corneal clouding/dendrites, may have associated skin vesicles.

content.text: All infants with conjunctivitis require a thorough evaluation, including conjunctival swabs for Gram stain, bacterial culture (including Thayer-Martin for N. gonorrhoeae), and NAAT for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae. HSV testing should be performed if suspected.

regimenData.notes: Hospitalization is required. The infant should be evaluated for disseminated infection. Saline irrigation of the eyes is also necessary.
Topical therapy is ineffective. Monitor for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). Azithromycin (20 mg/kg/day for 3 days) is an alternative.

durationDetail.fixedDuration: 14 days for localized disease, 21 days for disseminated or CNS disease

regimenData.notes: Requires immediate hospitalization and management by a pediatric infectious disease specialist. Topical therapy (e.g., trifluridine) is also indicated for ocular involvement.

content.text: Universal prophylaxis is administered to all newborns shortly after birth to prevent gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. Erythromycin (0.5%) ophthalmic ointment is the standard prophylactic agent used in the United States.
